title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions related to pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in providing training on literacy promotion to healthcare providers, delivering training curriculum, offering technical assistance, and integrating research into training for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. The "Prescribe A Book Act" allows facilities to obtain books at discounts and integrates developmental research into healthcare provider training. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program promotes reading aloud to children aged 6 months to 5 years. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes reading aloud to children through various means: healthcare providers giving books to children aged 6 months to 5 years, volunteers reading to children in waiting areas, and research showing positive effects on parent behavior and children's language skills. The "Prescribe A Book Act" authorizes grants for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit applications to receive grants and provide matching funds of at least 50%. Grant funds can be used for various literacy initiatives. An eligible entity receiving a grant under section 5622 must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies to establish and operate Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Contractors must prioritize serving at-risk children, particularly those from low-income families in high-poverty areas. The entity must provide training and technical assistance to contractors and include terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. Children eligible for assistance include those from low-income families, those without adequate medical insurance, those enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP programs, those in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited library access. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts before making payments. Eligible entities must report annually on program effectiveness. A conforming amendment is made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act is amended to include a new subpart for pediatric early literacy programs, outlining definitions, program authorization, application process, matching requirements, fund usage, payment restrictions, and reporting obligations. Eligible entities must have book arrangements for discounts and report annually on program effectiveness.
